docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, the health insurer, posted a loss yesterday for the second quarter as membership rolls shrank and it set aside more money for its former reinsurance business. The net loss was $53 million, or 38 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $215 million, or $1.50 a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 2.2 percent, to $4.6 billion.

headline.main: Cigna Reports $53 Million Loss in Second Quarter

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp reports second-quarter loss of $53 million compared to net income of $215 million year earlier; revenue fell 2.2 percent, to $4.6 billion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP., El Segundo, Calif., a maker of semiconductors, said that it had $721 million on its balance sheet and that it would use its cash for acquisitions. LABONE INC., Lenexa, Kan., a conductor of tests for insurance companies and drug screening for employers, said it would acquire an insurance-testing laboratory in Elmsford, N.Y., from MetLife Inc., New York, and provide laboratory services to MetLife. Terms were not disclosed.

docs.lead_paragraph: You simply cannot get it all in one story. That was surely the case with an opinion poll on religion and politics conducted in late June and early July by the Pew Research Center and Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life. Widespread reports of the poll focused, reasonably enough, on two subjects: Americans' increasingly critical view of Islam and increasingly favorable view of gay marriage.

headline.main: Beliefs; A new poll gauges the evolving American attitudes about Islam and about gay marriage.

docs.abstract: Peter Steinfels comments opinion poll on religion and politics conducted in late June and early July by Pew Research Center and Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life; poll focuses on Americans' increasingly critical view of Islam, and increasingly favorable view of gay marriage; number of Americans believing that Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its adherents has grown sharply over last year, even though favorable view of Muslim-Americans remains little changed (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PEW FORUM ON RELIGION AND PUBLIC LIFE

docs.lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, I remember my parents telling me that going to college would broaden my horizons and give me all the opportunities in the world. What I've found out, though, is that the benefits of being a student become clouded when you add the word ''athlete.'' That's because the National Collegiate Athletic Association not only rules college athletics, it also limits the opportunities of the 360,000 student-athletes it purports to serve. The N.C.A.A. was formed a century ago to establish rules for intercollegiate competition, and it did an admirable job. Today, however, it has become a multibillion-dollar organization that holds a monopoly on college athletics. Much of the television royalties and other revenue of college athletics go directly to the N.C.A.A., which distributes the money as it sees fit to its 1,200 member institutions. As the organization has smoothly adapted to the big-money era of college athletics, it has kept the student-athletes themselves from benefiting from the changes.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Colorado football player Jeremy Bloom charges that NCAA has smoothly adapted to big-money era of college athletics while keeping student-athletes from benefiting; explains how policies harm student-athletes, noting that in his own case he had to give up endorsement opportunities as Olympic skier in order to play football; proposes Student-Athletes' Bill of Rights, which would permit other employment and royalties from apparel sales (M)
